abstract: We propose a biologically inspired multi-agent system that evolves novel communication protocols over time to coordinate disaster response tasks in unknown environments. The system uses reinforcement learning to adapt agent-to-agent language, enabling autonomous teams to perform complex search-and-rescue missions with minimal human supervision.

This paper introduces a chrome extension that highlights AI-generated text in online articles using a simple BERT classifier. While similar tools exist, our version integrates seamlessly with news sites and offers a transparent confidence score for flagged sections.

We develop a personalized exam preparation system that uses retrieval-augmented generation and memory modeling to test student recall and recommend reinforcement exercises. The system adapts difficulty using spaced repetition and concept graph embedding.

We present a decentralized platform for crowdsourced fact verification, where claims are evaluated through a blockchain-backed credibility protocol. Users stake tokens on factual correctness, incentivizing accurate information curation.

This work revisits the classic PageRank algorithm, applying it to academic collaboration networks to suggest productive new co-author connections. We integrate this with DBLP metadata to build a simple dashboard for researchers.

We introduce an interactive visualization tool that explains neural network decisions using counterfactual feature attributions. Our system helps students and researchers visually explore what features drive classification boundaries in image models.

We propose an embodied AI assistant that integrates real-time EEG feedback to modulate its behavior during high-stress collaboration. The system learns to adaptively reduce cognitive load using bio-signal guided reinforcement.

This project investigates the effectiveness of classical encryption schemes when applied to low-latency IoT devices. We simulate constrained devices and benchmark performance across several block ciphers.
We propose a system that learns to simulate realistic traffic environments using generative models trained on city camera footage. The simulator is optimized for training autonomous vehicle policies.
We explore the use of synthetic question generation to improve domain adaptation in QA systems. The model generates curriculum-aligned questions from textbook text using fine-tuned T5.
This work presents a comparative study of multi-modal recommendation systems across movie, book, and retail domains. We evaluate user-item alignment using attention-based fusion layers.
We replicate a classic study in NLP sentiment classification using modern transformer-based embeddings and show that gains over LSTM models are minimal under strong regularization.
We present a new dataset of annotated satellite images for evaluating flood prediction models. The dataset is curated with help from humanitarian groups and comes with geospatial metadata.
We introduce a reactive swarm system for warehouse robotics where agents can dynamically change goals based on real-time supply chain demands and inventory levels.
This work evaluates the performance of compression algorithms on time-series data collected from industrial sensors, with a focus on accuracy-vs-latency tradeoffs.
We propose a soft attention mechanism that integrates historical behavioral sequences to improve click-through rate prediction in ad recommendation systems.
We design a system for rapid post-disaster damage assessment by combining drone footage with 3D mesh reconstruction and neural radiance fields.
We present a plug-and-play module for transformer models that enhances performance on small data regimes by injecting low-rank structure into attention matrices.
This paper surveys 50 years of graph coloring algorithms, providing a taxonomy and practical benchmarking on scheduling and register allocation tasks.
We build a web-based IDE that offers real-time collaboration with semantic version tracking and GPT-assisted bug explanation for novice coders.
We propose a knowledge-augmented chatbot that learns from GitHub issues, StackOverflow threads, and documentation to support software engineering teams in real-time.
We study the social dynamics of crowdsourced annotation platforms, modeling worker disagreement using opinion dynamics to improve label aggregation methods.
We revisit data deduplication strategies for archival storage and propose a hybrid hash+pattern matching approach that reduces redundancy with minimal metadata.
This work investigates noise-aware preprocessing pipelines for wearable sensor data used in continuous health monitoring.
We develop a semantic code browser that clusters large codebases into topics using transformer embeddings and hierarchy-aware topic modeling.

I envision an AI-driven system that studies seismic patterns, geospatial data, and real-time environmental signals to predict earthquakes before they happen. This isn’t just an app. It’s a mission to save lives. Evacuations could happen in time. Infrastructure could be safeguarded. It’s time we use AI to prepare—not just react—to nature’s power.

I envision a long-form narrative analyzer that doesn’t just summarize, but understands the deep, evolving relationships between characters, ideas, and authors. It would track plot arcs, emotion shifts, and historical context across chapters—or across decades of scholarship. This isn’t just for fun—it would transform education, criticism, and even scientific discovery by showing how ideas evolve over time.

I envision a tool designed to address the problem of disinformation in the digital age: The Contextualizer. Instead of being just another search engine, it is a sense-making engine that uses conversational and semantic AI to understand intent, detect bias, and analyze the broader context of any content. Whether it's a headline, social media post, or policy brief, the tool evaluates credibility and compiles multiple perspectives. By reconstructing timelines and surfacing deeper context, it enables users to better understand the full picture, empowering critical thinking rather than replacing it.

I envision a deep culture translator that helps bridge the gaps in global communication. While translation tools have improved, they often miss the nuanced emotions and assumptions tied to cultural contexts. This tool would use AI to model how different societies interpret words, ideas, and emotions. It wouldn’t just translate language, but meaning—connecting how people express and understand social interactions across diverse cultures. This could be powerful in international workplaces, diplomacy, and even education.

I envision an AI-powered assistant to support doctors by listening during patient consultations, auto-generating summaries and suggesting treatments based on history and clinical guidelines. This system would also surface the most relevant research updates for each physician’s specialty. With less time on paperwork and more time on patient care, doctors can make faster, more informed decisions. By integrating into clinical workflows, this agent would turn overwhelming medical data into practical, real-time support.

I envision a Personal Knowledge Curator—an intelligent system that captures, tags, and organizes information from everything we read, watch, or hear. This AI companion would connect concepts across fields, personalize recommendations, and make it easier to recall what we’ve encountered. Students could use it to prepare for exams more effectively, while professionals could stay current in fast-moving fields. Ultimately, it wouldn’t just store knowledge—it would spark creativity and help people grow.

I envision an intelligent life assistant that reduces digital decision fatigue. This system would categorize content based on user-defined preferences, help generate personalized daily routines, and retrieve stored info using natural language. Whether managing tasks, accessing files, or deciding what to prioritize, it would simplify digital life. It aims to address the mental load of modern life by combining productivity with personalization and ease of use.

I envision a tool that helps people stay focused when using their devices. I often get distracted and think it would be helpful to have something that notices when I lose focus and gently nudges me back. Maybe it tracks usage patterns or provides reminders, but I haven’t figured out the details yet. I’d like to explore productivity tools and see how we can use simple AI to encourage better habits.

I envision a smarter daily planner that personalizes how tasks are scheduled and shown to users. Current tools often feel rigid. I imagine something lightweight that adjusts based on how you typically prioritize or complete things. I’m still thinking about what kind of interface or intelligence it would need, but I want to try building something in the productivity space.

I envision an adaptive learning platform that responds to how people learn best. Some people like visuals, others prefer audio or interaction. I’m not totally sure how to measure or adjust for learning styles, but I’d like to try making something that supports students in a more personalized way.

I envision a wellness tracker that’s casual and easy to use. Instead of having to log everything, it could use simple check-ins or background data to get a sense of how you're feeling. I’m interested in the intersection of tech and mental health, but haven’t worked on anything in that space yet.

I envision a tool that helps people clean up their social media feeds—maybe it learns what kind of posts you value and gradually filters out noise or negativity. I haven’t figured out how it would work with existing platforms, but it’s something I’ve thought about a lot and want to explore.
I envision joining a project where I can help build something useful. I don’t have a specific idea in mind, but I’m excited to contribute and learn along the way. I’m open to anything, really.

I envision working with a team to create something that uses tech in an interesting way. I haven’t thought about what the product would be, but I’m happy to go with whatever direction the group takes.
I envision participating in a group project that builds an app or website. I’m not set on any topic, and I think it’ll be fun to see what ideas come up as we go.
I envision contributing to a project that involves coding. I don’t have a clear preference for what the app should do, but I’d like to get better at working in teams and writing clean code.
I envision a project where I can take on tasks and be helpful. I don’t really have a vision for what we build, but I’m looking forward to building experience and seeing where it leads.
